elements.content: Three fluorescent coordination polymers (CPs) including [Zn­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)] (1), [Cd­(ppvppa)2­(2,5-FDC)]­·1.5H2O (2), and [Ni­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)]­·0.5MeCN (3) (ppvppa = dipyridin-2-yl-[4-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl]-amine; 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC = 5-nitroisophthalic acid and 2,5-H2FDC = 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid) were assembled from solvothermal reactions of Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O, Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O, or Ni­(NO3)2­·6H2O with ppvppa in the presence of 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC or 2,5-H2FDC. Compound 1 has a one-dimensional (1D) double-stranded chain structure. 2 and 3 have different two-dimensional (2D) grid-like networks formed by either bridging 1D [Cd­(ppvppa)2] n chains with 2,5-FDC ligands or linking 1D [Ni2(ppvppa)2] n chains with 5-NO2-1,3-BDC ligands. The ligand ppvppa and the three CPs could detect Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– in aqueous solutions by selective fluorescence quenching. The detection limit of the most responsive complex 3 was 1.39 ppb for Cr2O7 2– (pH = 4) or 0.09 ppb for CrO4 2– (pH = 12), which are below the allowable limits set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and European Union and the lowest among the known CPs-based sensors. The mechanism of such an emission quenching process may be ascribed to the overlap between the absorption band of the analyte and those of the excitation and emission bands of 3.

elements.content: A two-dimensional coordination polymer [Ni­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)] could selectively detect Cr2O7 2− and CrO4 2− in water by fluorescence quenching, and its detection limits are 1.39 ppb for Cr2O7 2− (pH = 4) and 0.09 ppb for CrO4 2− (pH = 12), which are lower than the allowable limits set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and European Union and those observed for most known coordination polymer-based luminescent sensors.

elements.content: Cr­(VI) species are widely used in industry and agriculture and have been classified as serious pollutants by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Long-term exposure to Cr­(VI) ions, even at low concentrations, can cause adverse health effects including allergic reactions, hereditary genetic defects, and lung cancer. Therefore, rapid detection of Cr­(VI) ions in water at very low concentrations is essential for the environment, human health, and food security.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Cr(VI) species are widely used in industry and agriculture and have been classified as serious pollutants by the United States Environmental Protection Agency. Long-term exposure to Cr(VI) ions, even at low concentrations, can cause adverse health effects including allergic reactions, hereditary genetic defects, and lung cancer. Therefore, rapid detection of Cr(VI) ions in water at very low concentrations is essential for the environment, human health, and food security.

elements.content: Recently, functional coordination polymers (CPs) have been extensively investigated due to their structure diversities and numerous applications in energy storage/conversion, organic catalysis, sensors, optics, pollution treatment, electronics and so on. Luminescent CPs have received particular attention because they can be employed for selective and sensitive probes for detecting environmental pollutants. Some luminescent CPs of aromatic organic ligands have the potential for practical applications in light-emitting diodes (LEDs). The fluorescent emission strength and wavelength of their structural motifs can be finely tuned by rational incorporation of diverse metal centers and different conjugated aromatic organic linkers. Emission peaks of aromatic organic linkers are generally attributed to the π* → n or π → π* transitions. Various pyridyl-appended π-conjugated materials have been proven to be highly selective and sensitive chemosensors for toxic ions.

Emission peaks of aromatic organic linkers are generally attributed to the π* → n or π → π* transitions. Various pyridyl-appended π-conjugated materials have been proven to be highly selective and sensitive chemosensors for toxic ions.

elements.content: In our previous works, we prepared a series of CPs by the assembly of 1,3,5-tri-4-pyridyl-1,2-ethenylbenzene with Zn­(II) and investigated their performances in the luminescent detection of Cr3+ ions in aqueous media. Recently, we have reported the luminescent selective detection of Hg2+ and MeHgI by using dipyridin-2-yl-[4-(2-pyridin-4-yl-vinyl)-phenyl]-amine (ppvppa) () and its zinc coordination polymer [Zn­(ppvppa)­(1,4-NDC)]. In the present work, we have extended this study to other luminescent CPs assembled from reactions from Zn­(II), Cd­(II), or Ni­(II) salt with ppvppa under solvothermal conditions. Three novel luminescent CPs including [Zn­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)] (1), [Cd­(ppvppa)2(2,5-FDC)]·1.5H2O (2), and [Ni­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)]2·MeCN (3) were isolated and structurally characterized. The ligand ppvppa and three CPs 1–3 were luminescent and have been confirmed to be highly selective sensors for two Cr­(VI) anions (Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2–) in water, and compound 3 showed superior capabilities in the selective detection of both anions in water with very low detection limits. Described below are their synthesis, structural characterization, and luminescent sensing performances.

Described below are their synthesis, structural characterization, and luminescent sensing performances.

Experimental Section

General Procedures

The ligand ppvppa was prepared according to the literature method, while the analytical instruments used in this work are the same as those reported previously. Other chemicals and reagents were obtained directly from commercial sources and used as received.

elements.content: To a Pyrex glass tube was added Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (3.94 mg, 0.02 mmol), 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (4.22 mg, 0.02 mmol), ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol), and 2 mL of MeCN/H2O (v/v = 1:3), which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 48 h. After slowly being cooled to ambient temperature, yellow crystals of 1 were formed several days later, which were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. Yield: 10.16 mg (79% based on Zn). Anal. calcd (%) for C31H23N5O7Zn: C, 57.90, N, 10.89, H, 3.61; found: C, 57.97, N, 10.99, H, 3.87. elements.content: Single crystals of 1, 2, and 3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. Data were obtained on an Bruker D8 QUEST X-ray diffractometer using a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 223 K. An adsorption correction (multiscan) was performed with the program SADABS, and the reflection data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. All structures were solved by the direct method and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-2016 Program. In 2 and 3, the solvent molecules were unable to get a satisfied location and thus were treated as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom positions by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located at the geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of their key crystal data and refinement parameters is provided in .
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystallography

Single crystals of 1, 2, and 3 suitable for X-ray analysis were obtained directly from the above preparations. Data were obtained on an Bruker D8 QUEST X-ray diffractometer using a graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) radiation at 223 K. An adsorption correction (multiscan) was performed with the program SADABS, and the reflection data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects. All structures were solved by the direct method and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares using the SHELXL-2016 Program. In 2 and 3, the solvent molecules were unable to get a satisfied location and thus were treated as a diffuse contribution to the overall scattering without specific atom positions by the SQUEEZE routine of PLATON. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Hydrogen atoms were located at the geometrically idealized positions and constrained to ride on their parent atoms. A summary of their key crystal data and refinement parameters is provided in .

Compounds 1–3 were prepared by the one-pot solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O (or Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O or Ni­(NO3)2­·6H2O with ppvppa and 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (or 2,5-H2FDC) in a ratio of 1:1:1 and 2:1:2, respectively. Changing the molar ratios of components and the pH values of the solutions did not increase the yields of 1–3. Compounds 1–3 were relatively air and moisture stable, and insoluble in water and common organic solvents such as MeOH and EtOH. Their elemental analyses were consistent with their chemical formulas. The IR spectra of 1–3 featured the absorption bands at 1609–1631 cm–1 and 1322–1471 cm–1 attributable to the coordinated dicarboxylate (5-NO2-1,3-BDC and 2,5-FDC) ligands. According to the thermogravimetric analyses of 1–3 (Figure S1), the loss of 1.5 H2O lattice molecules (2.38%, calcd. 2.72%) at 30–100 °C (2) or the loss of 0.5 MeCN solvent molecules (3.13%, calcd. 3.12%) at 30–100 °C (3) was observed at the first stage. Then the coordinated H2O molecules in 1 (2.38%, calcd. 2.80%) and 3 (2.22%, calcd. 2.39%) got lost in the range of 55–135 °C (1) or 110–310 °C (3). All organic ligands (87.0%, calcd. 86.1% for 1; 86.0%, calcd. 89.1% for 2; 85.2%, calcd 78.6% for 3) were finally removed in the range of 318–550 °C (1), 290–537 °C (2), and 310–470 °C (3), respectively. The residual species were assumed to be ZnO (11.5%, calcd 12.7%) for 1, CdO (8.7%, calcd 13.2%) for 2, and NiO (15.9%, calcd 11.4%) for 3.

Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Structural Characterization

Compounds 1-3 were prepared by the one-pot solvothermal reaction of Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (or Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O or Ni(NO3)2⋅6H2O with ppvppa and 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (or 2,5-H2FDC) in a ratio of 1:1:1 and 2:1:2, respectively. Changing the molar ratios of components and the pH values of the solutions did not increase the yields of 1-3. Compounds 1-3 were relatively air and moisture stable, and insoluble in water and common organic solvents such as MeOH and EtOH. Their elemental analyses were consistent with their chemical formulas. The IR spectra of 1-3 featured the absorption bands at 1609-1631 cm-1 and 1322-1471 cm-1 attributable to the coordinated dicarboxylate (5-NO2-1,3-BDC and 2,5-FDC) ligands. According to the thermogravimetric analyses of 1-3 (Figure S1), the loss of 1.5 H2O lattice molecules (2.38%, calcd. 2.72%) at 30-100 °C (2) or the loss of 0.5 MeCN solvent molecules (3.13%, calcd. 3.12%) at 30-100 °C (3) was observed at the first stage. Then the coordinated H2O molecules in 1 (2.38%, calcd. 2.80%) and 3 (2.22%, calcd. 2.39%) got lost in the range of 55-135 °C (1) or 110-310 °C (3). All organic ligands (87.0%, calcd. 86.1% for 1; 86.0%, calcd. 89.1% for 2; 85.2%, calcd 78.6% for 3) were finally removed in the range of 318-550 °C (1), 290-537 °C (2), and 310-470 °C (3), respectively. The residual species were assumed to be ZnO (11.5%, calcd 12.7%) for 1, CdO (8.7%, calcd 13.2%) for 2, and NiO (15.9%, calcd 11.4%) for 3.

elements.content: The water stability of ppvppa and 1–3 was investigated at aqueous solutions of various pH values with phosphate buffered saline (PBS, 0.1 mol/L). Notably, solid ppvppa and 1–3 could partially dissolve in water at pH < 4. Thus, each powdered sample was suspended in water in a pH range from 4 to 12 for 1 h. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns for each solid sample of ppvppa and 1–3 after treating them in either acidic or basic aqueous solutions agreed well with those simulated from crystal data of the corresponding compound (Figure S2). The results indicated that ppvppa and 1–3 exhibited good water stability in a pH range from 4 to 12 and could be used as candidates for fluorescent detection of Cr­(VI) anions in aqueous media as described below.

elements.content: Compound 1 crystallizes in the monoclinic P21/c space group, and its asymmetric unit contains one [Zn­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)] unit. Each Zn­(II) has a trigonal bypyramidal coordination geometry, coordinated by three O atoms from three 5-NO2-1,3-BDC ligands, one N atom from a ppvppa, and one O atom from H2O (a). The two carboxylate groups of the 5-NO2-1,3-BDC ligand exhibit one monodentate mode and one μ-η1(O)-η1(O) bridging mode. Two zinc centers are bridged by two 5-NO2-1,3-BDC to form a centrosymmetric dimeric fragment [Zn­(ppvppa)­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)­(H2O)]2. Such a fragment is connected to its equivalent ones by linking two Zn­(II) centers via another pair of 5-NO2-1,3-BDC ligands, forming a one-dimensional (1D) double chain (extending along the b axis) with pendant ppvppa ligands being arranged symmetrically at both sides (b). Each ppvppa works as a monodentate ligand with the dipyridinylamine group uncoordinated.

elements.content: Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c, and its asymmetric unit contains one [Cd­(ppvppa)2­(2,5-FDC)2] unit. Each Cd­(II) center is seven-coordinated by five O atoms from three 2,5-FDC ligands and two N atoms from two ppvppa ligands to form a distorted pentagonal bipyramidal coordination geometry (a). The two carboxylate groups of the 2,5-FDC ligand display one chalete mode and one μ-η1(O)-η2(O) bridging mode. Two Cd­(II) centers are bridged by two 2,5-FDC ligands to form a centrosymmetric dimeric fragment [Cd­(ppvppa)­(2,5-FDC)]2. Such a fragment is interconnected to its four equivalent ones by linking two Cd­(II) centers via another pairs of 2,5-FDC ligands, forming a 2D layer (extending along the bc plane) (b) with pendant ppvppa ligands being arranged symmetrically above and below the 2D [Cd­(2,5-FDC)] n plane (c). The dipyridinylamine group of each ppvppa remains intact.

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/n, and its asymmetric unit contains one [Ni2(ppvppa)2­(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)2­(H2O)2] unit. Each Ni­(II) is octahedrally coordinated by two O atoms form two monodentate 5-NO2-1,3-BDC linkers, two N atoms from the dipyridinylamine group of one bridging ppvppa, one N atom from the pyridyl group of another bridging ppvppa and one O atom from one H2O molecule (a). The combination of four Ni­(II) centers and four 5-NO2-1,3-BDC linkers yields a rhombic-shaped grid fragment [Ni4(5-NO2-1,3-BDC)4] (b), which acts as a 4-connecting node. Each fragment is further interlinked to its equivalent ones through four pairs of bridging ppvppa ligands to yield a 2D network (c).

elements.content: The ppvppa ligand had a strong photoluminescence emission at 485 nm at pH = 12 and 555 nm at pH = 4. A finely ground sample of ppvppa (3 mg) was immersed in 3 mL of different calcium salt aqueous solutions with the same concentration (0.01 M) containing F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, IO3 –, ClO4 –, P2O7 4–, NO3 –, CO3 2–, SO4 2–, Cr2O7 2–, and CrO4 2– anions. When the pH value of each solution was fixed to be 4, the presence of F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, IO3 –, ClO4 –, P2O7 4–, NO3 –, CO3 2–, and SO4 2– only slightly decreased the luminescence intensity of ppvppa at 555 nm (a). However, the Cr2O7 2– anion caused much larger luminescence quenching at the same conditions. At pH = 12, F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, IO3 –, ClO4 –, P2O7 4–, NO3 –, CO3 2–, and SO4 2– anions also did not cause much decrease of the luminescence of ppvppa at 485 nm (b). Only CrO4 2– made a significant luminescence quenching under the same conditions. The results indicate the high selectivity of ppvppa for Cr2O7 2– (pH = 4) and CrO4 2– (pH = 12) anions over other anions.
elements.clean_text:
Probing Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- in Water Using ppvppa as a Luminescent Sensor

The ppvppa ligand had a strong photoluminescence emission at 485 nm at pH = 12 and 555 nm at pH = 4. A finely ground sample of ppvppa (3 mg) was immersed in 3 mL of different calcium salt aqueous solutions with the same concentration (0.01 M) containing F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, IO3 -, ClO4 -, P2O7 4-, NO3 -, CO3 2-, SO4 2-, Cr2O7 2-, and CrO4 2- anions. When the pH value of each solution was fixed to be 4, the presence of F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, IO3 -, ClO4 -, P2O7 4-, NO3 -, CO3 2-, and SO4 2- only slightly decreased the luminescence intensity of ppvppa at 555 nm (a). However, the Cr2O7 2- anion caused much larger luminescence quenching at the same conditions. At pH = 12, F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, IO3 -, ClO4 -, P2O7 4-, NO3 -, CO3 2-, and SO4 2- anions also did not cause much decrease of the luminescence of ppvppa at 485 nm (b). Only CrO4 2- made a significant luminescence quenching under the same conditions. The results indicate the high selectivity of ppvppa for Cr2O7 2- (pH = 4) and CrO4 2- (pH = 12) anions over other anions.

Emission spectra of ppvppa in H2O with the addition of different concentrations of Cr2O7 2– (c) and CrO4 2– (d), and the corresponding Stern–Volmer curves (e).

Emission spectra of ppvppa in H2O with the addition of different concentrations of Cr2O7 2- (c) and CrO4 2- (d), and the corresponding Stern-Volmer curves (e).

elements.content: The aforementioned anion selective quenching behavior was quantified by systematically varying the concentrations of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2–. Titration experiments indicated that the luminescence intensity of ppvppa was gradually weakened with the addition of Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– anions (c,d) with a linear dependency in each case (e). The luminescence of ppvppa was almost completely quenched at 105 μM and 114 μM for Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions, respectively. The relative luminescence intensities with changes in the concentrations of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions obeyed a Stern–Volmer relationship: I 0/I = 30780 × [Cr2O7 2–] + 1.01373, R 2 = 0.98168) (for Cr2O7 2–), and I 0/I = 71260 × [CrO4 2–] + 0.8978, R 2 = 0.99725) (for CrO4 2–). Detection limits were calculated to be 70.49 ppb for Cr2O7 2– and 193.57 ppb for CrO4 2– (e). Such relatively low detection limits, comparable with those observed for some known complexes (Table S4), suggested that the Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions are the efficient quenchers for the fluorescence of ppvppa. The PXRD patterns of ppvppa after exposure to Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions in aqueous solutions for 12 h demonstrated that it remained almost intact (Figure S3).

The relative luminescence intensities with changes in the concentrations of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- anions obeyed a Stern-Volmer relationship: I 0/I = 30780 × [Cr2O7 2-] + 1.01373, R 2 = 0.98168) (for Cr2O7 2-), and I 0/I = 71260 × [CrO4 2-] + 0.8978, R 2 = 0.99725) (for CrO4 2-). Detection limits were calculated to be 70.49 ppb for Cr2O7 2- and 193.57 ppb for CrO4 2- (e). Such relatively low detection limits, comparable with those observed for some known complexes (Table S4), suggested that the Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- anions are the efficient quenchers for the fluorescence of ppvppa. The PXRD patterns of ppvppa after exposure to Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- anions in aqueous solutions for 12 h demonstrated that it remained almost intact (Figure S3).

elements.content: In comparison with free ppvppa ligand, upon excitation at 370 nm, an aqueous suspension of a finely ground crystalline sample of 1–3 exhibited a strong luminescent emission peak with maxima at 485 nm (1 and 3) and 420 nm (2) at pH = 4, and at 555 nm (1–3) at pH = 12. Uniform suspensions of 1–3 were prepared by grinding the crystalline solid (3 mg) and suspending the powders in deionized water (3 mL) through ultrasound mixing for 1 h. Each aqueous solution (3 mol/L, 1 μL) of K n X (F–, Cl–, Br–, I–, IO3 –, ClO4 –, P2O7 4–, NO3 –, CO3 2–, SO4 2–, Cr2O7 2–, and CrO4 2–, n = 1, 2, 4) was injected into the suspension by microsyringe and uniformly mixed at room temperature. The luminescence intensities of the resulting suspension were measured on a spectrofluorometer (a,b, Figures S4–S7 and Figures S8–S11). The fluorescent quenching of 1–3 by these anions was similar to that reported for other fluorescent CPs (Table S4). Compounds 1–3 can detect Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– in solution, and thus there was a potential for them to be used as chemical sensors for the detection of such important pollutants in water.

Probing Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- in Water Using 1-3 as Luminescent Sensors

In comparison with free ppvppa ligand, upon excitation at 370 nm, an aqueous suspension of a finely ground crystalline sample of 1-3 exhibited a strong luminescent emission peak with maxima at 485 nm (1 and 3) and 420 nm (2) at pH = 4, and at 555 nm (1-3) at pH = 12. Uniform suspensions of 1-3 were prepared by grinding the crystalline solid (3 mg) and suspending the powders in deionized water (3 mL) through ultrasound mixing for 1 h. Each aqueous solution (3 mol/L, 1 μL) of K n X (F-, Cl-, Br-, I-, IO3 -, ClO4 -, P2O7 4-, NO3 -, CO3 2-, SO4 2-, Cr2O7 2-, and CrO4 2-, n = 1, 2, 4) was injected into the suspension by microsyringe and uniformly mixed at room temperature. The luminescence intensities of the resulting suspension were measured on a spectrofluorometer (a,b, Figures S4-S7 and Figures S8-S11). The fluorescent quenching of 1-3 by these anions was similar to that reported for other fluorescent CPs (Table S4). Compounds 1-3 can detect Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- in solution, and thus there was a potential for them to be used as chemical sensors for the detection of such important pollutants in water.

elements.content: After careful examination of the quenching performances of 1–3, compound 3 displayed the most remarkable quenching in the presence of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– in aqueous solutions () and thus was chosen as a model compound for further investigation of selectivity and sensitivity. Exposure to Cr2O7 2– anion at pH = 4 resulted in a significant fluorescence quenching (a), while other anions had only a slight effect on the fluorescent intensity at 555 nm. When the pH value of the solution was fixed at 12, only CrO4 2– resulted in a noteworthy luminescence quenching at 485 nm (b). These findings revealed a high selectivity of 3 toward Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions compared to other common mono- and divalent anions.

Exposure to Cr2O7 2- anion at pH = 4 resulted in a significant fluorescence quenching (a), while other anions had only a slight effect on the fluorescent intensity at 555 nm. When the pH value of the solution was fixed at 12, only CrO4 2- resulted in a noteworthy luminescence quenching at 485 nm (b). These findings revealed a high selectivity of 3 toward Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- anions compared to other common mono- and divalent anions.

elements.content: Titration experiments revealed that the luminescence intensity of 3 was gradually weakened by the addition of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions (c,d) in a linear manner (e). The luminescence of 3 was almost completely quenched at concentrations of 170 μM and 70 μM for Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions, respectively. The relative luminescence intensity of 3 at varying concentrations of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions fitted the Stern–Volmer equation: I 0/I = 21396 × [Cr2O7 2–] + 0.78798, R 2 = 0.99385 (for Cr2O7 2–), and I 0/I = 210526 × [CrO4 2–] + 0.37042 and R 2 = 0.99284 (for CrO4 2–) (e). Notably, the detection limits were calculated to be 1.39 ppb (for Cr2O7 2–) and 0.09 ppb (for CrO4 2–), which are remarkably lower than the corresponding ones observed for ppvppa and some reported compounds (Table S4). The framework of 3 remained intact after exposure to Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– as confirmed by PXRD patterns (Figure S12). Luminescence could be regenerated when solid sample 3 was centrifuged from the solution containing these analytes. Multiple cycles of exposing 3 to aqueous solution of Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– followed by washing with deionized water indicated the restoration of its photoluminescent intensity ().

Multiple cycles of exposing 3 to aqueous solution of Cr2O7 2- or CrO4 2- followed by washing with deionized water indicated the restoration of its photoluminescent intensity ().

elements.content: As is well-known, the luminescence quenching by anions is mainly due to the following aspects: (1) structural collapse of the CP framework; (2) interactions between the anions and the framework or central metal; (3) competitive adsorption of excitation or emission frequencies. Initially, we examined the first possibility by investigating the PXRD patterns of 3 before and after exposure to the aqueous solution of each analyte (Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2–) (Figure S12). The main structure of 3 after an immersion in a solution of each anion was almost unchanged. The second possibility may be ruled out because Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions have very weak interactions with the framework or central metal. We next investigated the possibility of overlap between absorption and emission spectra for each analyte (Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2–) and the sensing species (3). The observed changes in the luminescence intensity may be ascribed to the energy transfer between Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– anion and the π and π* orbitals of the ppvppa ligands in 3. According to the UV–vis absorption spectra, Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– had wide absorption bands in the UV–vis region from 275 to 476 nm for Cr2O7 2– and 230 to 450 nm for CrO4 2–, which overlapped with the excitation and/or emission bands of 3 (Figure S13), implying that the competitive adsorption of the excitation and emission wavelength energy between 3 and Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– anion was highly responsible for the observed luminescence quenching. For 1–3, the spectral overlap area generated by 3 and Cr2O7 2– (blue shadow) or CrO4 2– (red shadow) was larger than that of 1 (or 2) and the chromium ions (Figure S13), suggesting that 3 exhibited the most remarkable quenching in the presence of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– in aqueous solutions.

elements.content: For the possible luminescence quenching mechanism, we carried out an experiment to examine whether the energy transfer resulted in the observed quenching effect. As shown in a, two quartz cells were employed to hold the suspension of 3 and Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– (2 × 10–3 mol/L) in PBS. When pH = 4 or 12, the suspension of 3 was placed in position A, while Cr2O7 2– (pH = 4) or CrO4 2– (pH = 12) was placed in the excitation path (position B) or emission path (position C), respectively. Under excitation at 370 nm, the luminescent intensities of 3 (black curves) and 3 with chromium ions inserted into the excitation path (pastel green curves) or the emission path (radiant orchid curves) were compared to that of the mixture of 3 with chromium ions (red curves). When the Cr2O7 2– or CrO4 2– solution was placed in the excitation path, the luminescence of 3 was remarkably reduced (Figure S13). When put in the emission path, CrO4 2– also absorbed much of the emission light, whereas the effect of Cr2O7 2– was rather small. These results demonstrated that the luminescent quenching of 3 by Cr2O7 2– could be attributed to the energy transfer from the excitation light to the Cr2O7 2– ion, while that by CrO4 2– was ascribed to the energy transfers from both excitation and emission processes to the dissolved CrO4 2– anion.

elements.content: In summary, we have demonstrated that three luminescent CPs (1–3) were successfully constructed from the π-conjugated ligand ppvppa and Zi­(II), Cd­(II), or Ni­(II) in the presence of 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC or 2,5-H2FDC. Compounds 1–3 have a 1D double chain structure (1) or two different types of 2D grid-like networks (2 and 3). Strong photoluminescence coupled with good water stability over a wide pH range proved to be ideal candidates for the efficient and selective sensing of Cr2O7 2– and CrO4 2– anions in water. The detection limits for the most efficient complex 3 were 1.39 ppb for Cr2O7 2– (pH = 4) and 0.09 ppb for CrO4 2– (pH = 12), which are well below the permissible limits for these anions set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the European Union and the lowest so far reported for functional CPs-based sensing materials (Table S4). Our present work provided interesting insight into the assembly of the most fluorescent CP-based sensing materials from rationally designed organic linkers and suitable metal ions and revealed the great potential for the luminescent detection of hazardous metal ions in wastewater by using these sensors.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In summary, we have demonstrated that three luminescent CPs (1-3) were successfully constructed from the π-conjugated ligand ppvppa and Zi(II), Cd(II), or Ni(II) in the presence of 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC or 2,5-H2FDC. Compounds 1-3 have a 1D double chain structure (1) or two different types of 2D grid-like networks (2 and 3). Strong photoluminescence coupled with good water stability over a wide pH range proved to be ideal candidates for the efficient and selective sensing of Cr2O7 2- and CrO4 2- anions in water. The detection limits for the most efficient complex 3 were 1.39 ppb for Cr2O7 2- (pH = 4) and 0.09 ppb for CrO4 2- (pH = 12), which are well below the permissible limits for these anions set by the United States Environmental Protection Agency and the European Union and the lowest so far reported for functional CPs-based sensing materials (Table S4). Our present work provided interesting insight into the assembly of the most fluorescent CP-based sensing materials from rationally designed organic linkers and suitable metal ions and revealed the great potential for the luminescent detection of hazardous metal ions in wastewater by using these sensors.

To a Pyrex glass tube was added Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (3.94 mg, 0.02 mmol), 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (4.22 mg, 0.02 mmol), ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol), and 2 mL of MeCN/H2O (v/v = 1:3), which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 48 h. After slowly being cooled to ambient temperature, yellow crystals of 1 were formed several days later, which were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. Yield: 10.16 mg (79% based on Zn). Anal. calcd (%) for C31H23N5O7Zn: C, 57.90, N, 10.89, H, 3.61; found: C, 57.97, N, 10.99, H, 3.87. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3419 (w), 3042 (w), 2927 (w), 1609 (s), 1595 (s), 1568 (s), 1509 (s), 1477 (s), 1471 (s), 1431 (s), 1336 (s), 1275 (s), 1168 (w), 1156 (w), 1068 (w), 1019 (s), 1002 (w), 978 (s), 840 (s), 776 (s), 747 (w), 650 (w).

Preparation of [Cd­(ppvppa)<sub>2</sub>(2,5-FDC)]·1.5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

To a Pyrex glass tube was added Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (3.08 mg, 0.01 mmol), 2,5-H2FDC (1.56 mg, 0.01 mmol), ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol), and 2 mL of MeCN/H2O (v/v = 1:3), which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 48 h. After slowly being cooled to ambient temperature, yellow crystals of 2 were formed several days later, which were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. Yield: 6.58 mg (68% based on Cd). Anal. calcd (%) for C52H43N9O6Cd: C 62.31, N 12.58, H 4.32; found: C 62.66, N 12.73, H, 4.61. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3424 (w), 3032 (w), 1631 (w), 1593 (s), 1567 (w), 1508 (s), 1469 (s), 1430 (s), 1365 (w), 1329 (s), 1270 (w), 1218 (w), 1197 (w), 1154 (w), 1180 (w), 1065 (w), 1015 (w), 976 (w), 856 (w), 772 (s), 741 (s), 706 (w), 654 (s), 623 (s), 549 (s), 506 (s).

Preparation of [Ni­(ppvppa)­(5-NO<sub>2</sub>-1,3-BDC)­(H<sub>2</sub>O)]<sub>2</sub>·MeCN (<bold>3</bold>)

To a Pyrex glass tube was added Ni­(NO3)2·6H2O (5.81 mg, 0.02 mmol), 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (4.22 mg, 0.02 mmol), ppvppa (7 mg, 0.02 mmol), and 2 mL of MeCN/H2O (v/v = 1:3), which was sealed and heated at 150 °C for 48 h. After slowly being cooled to ambient temperature, yellow crystals of 3 were formed several days later, which were collected by filtration, washed with ethanol, and dried in air. Yield: 11.20 mg (88% based on Ni). Anal. calcd (%) for C62H46N10O14Ni2: C 58.52, N 12.41, H 3.87; found: C 58.63, N 12.55, H, 3.96. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): 3387 (w), 3051 (w), 1628 (w), 1595 (s), 1565 (s), 1512 (s), 1482 (s), 1465 (s), 1448 (s), 1430 (s), 1394 (s), 1322 (s), 1278 (s), 1218 (s), 1188 (s), 1153 (s), 1105 (w), 1051 (w), 1019 (s), 906 (w), 869 (w), 842 (w), 822 (w), 804 (w), 774 (s), 763 (s), 750 (w), 692 (w), 650 (s), 616 (w), 590 (s), 544 (w).

Results and DiscussionSynthesis and Structural Characterization

Compounds 1–3 were prepared by the one-pot solvothermal reaction of Zn­(NO3)2­·6H2O (or Cd­(NO3)2­·4H2O or Ni­(NO3)2­·6H2O with ppvppa and 5-NO2-1,3-H2BDC (or 2,5-H2FDC) in a ratio of 1:1:1 and 2:1:2, respectively. Changing the molar ratios of components and the pH values of the solutions did not increase the yields of 1–3. Compounds 1–3 were relatively air and moisture stable, and insoluble in water and common organic solvents such as MeOH and EtOH. Their elemental analyses were consistent with their chemical formulas. The IR spectra of 1–3 featured the absorption bands at 1609–1631 cm–1 and 1322–1471 cm–1 attributable to the coordinated dicarboxylate (5-NO2-1,3-BDC and 2,5-FDC) ligands. According to the thermogravimetric analyses of 1–3 (Figure S1), the loss of 1.5 H2O lattice molecules (2.38%, calcd. 2.72%) at 30–100 °C (2) or the loss of 0.5 MeCN solvent molecules (3.13%, calcd. 3.12%) at 30–100 °C (3) was observed at the first stage. Then the coordinated H2O molecules in 1 (2.38%, calcd. 2.80%) and 3 (2.22%, calcd. 2.39%) got lost in the range of 55–135 °C (1) or 110–310 °C (3). All organic ligands (87.0%, calcd. 86.1% for 1; 86.0%, calcd. 89.1% for 2; 85.2%, calcd 78.6% for 3) were finally removed in the range of 318–550 °C (1), 290–537 °C (2), and 310–470 °C (3), respectively. The residual species were assumed to be ZnO (11.5%, calcd 12.7%) for 1, CdO (8.7%, calcd 13.2%) for 2, and NiO (15.9%, calcd 11.4%) for 3.
